Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: ACI: Secure and Effective Policy Enforcement in Software-Defined WANs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Software Defined Networking (SDN) is a rapidly emerging, open source technology which decouples the network control functions from the data itself. This allows network functions to be programmed by network operators, application owners and system administrators. Instituting a dynamic network policy that constantly changes represents a strategic shift in the management of networks, which currently are static in nature. However, the flexibility in configuration has security repercussions in that SDN has no inherent security mechanisms built into its design. Permissions for configuration of the network ? both one?s own and others - as well as coordination and visibility between networks are still open technical questions. SDN has recently been adopted by a handful of major enterprise providers for limited use within their data centers, where robust security is less of an issue since the traffic stays within one network. However, as the Research and Education community and industry both look to adopt large scale SDN on their network backbones, the lack of a security framework for interdomain SDN use is a glaring vulnerability. This project defines the security architecture for large scale SDN networks and lays out a security coordination protocol for the largest use case for SDN, Wide Area Networking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project designed and prototyped new security services to protect large-scale software defined networks (SDNs). SDNs have been evaluated in test deployments by major Tier 1 providers, data centers, and mobile network operators.  The security of such networks is vitally important to societies that depend on reliable and trustworthy information infrastructures. However, the highly distributed nature of control planes among emerging SDN wide area network (WAN) designs offers several fundamental challenges in distributed policy synchronization, revocation, WAN privacy assurance, and the mediation of policy conflicts among SDN applications.  The project explored the following approaches to integrating new security services into SDN-enabled wide area network (WAN) environments.  First, the project prototyped a unique set of security feature extensions to the ONLAB Open Source Network Operating System (ONOS) system, called Security-Mode ONOS (published in ACSAC 2017). Security-Mode ONOS focuses on the integration of administrative security policy enforcement mechanisms that allow operators to control the privileges under which distributed ONOS applications may operate.  Second, the project supported the creations of a composable secure WAN-enabled SDN controller, called Barista (published in IEEE INFOCOM 2018). Barista enables the rapid modular prototyping, customization, and fielding of control layer logic to meet a wide-range of operational requirements found in many diverse network environments.  Third, the project investigated methods to integrate an anomaly detection development framework into existing SDN WAN infrastructures.  This work targeted large-scale network feature extraction and sophisticated anomaly detection services across the entire network data plane, not just at egress points. The system created, called Athena (published in IEEE/IFIP DSN 2017), offered the first SDN security monitor-generation framework that scales to large networks employing multiple controller instances across a distribute control plane.
